Highly efficient catalytic conversion of biomass-derived 2,5-dimethylfuran into renewable p-xylene over zirconium phosphate catalysts Chengming Wu Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft a b Ting Wu Data curation a Jifan Li Writing – review & editing a Chun-Ling Liu Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Wen-Sheng Dong Data curation Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University Xi’an 710062 China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, China b School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanjiang Normal University, Shiyan 442000, China School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanjiang Normal University Shiyan 442000 China School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanjiang Normal University, Shiyan 442000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A series of zirconium phosphates (ZrP-x) with various P/Zr ratios were prepared. Among the catalysts, ZrP-2.5 with a high specific surface area of 410.9 m2·g−1 and abundant mesopores exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in the synthesis of p-xylene (PX) from 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and ethylene. A high PX yield of 89.2% and a productivity of 72.3 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1 were achieved at 250 °C using a small amount of catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5 was attributed to the synergy between the large quantities of acidic sites with appropriate acid strength distribution, balanced Brønsted and Lewis acidity, and abundant mesopores. In addition, the catalyst had excellent recyclability and stability. In-situ FT-IR spectra of adsorbed DMF and ethylene revealed the crucial roles of P-OH and the coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV) in the adsorption and reaction process, which is beneficial to understanding the reaction mechanism and designing highly efficient catalysts. Graphical Abstract Zirconium phosphates prepared via a facile surfactant-free hydrothermal method exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the conversion of biomass-derived 2,5-dimethylfuran and ethylene to renewable p-xylene. ga1 Keywords 2,5-Dimethylfuran p-Xylene Zirconium phosphate In-situ infrared Mechanism Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction p-Xylene (PX), an important basic chemical raw materials, is industrially produced by the catalytic cracking of petroleum-derived naphtha [1,2]. With the continuous consumption of fossil resources and the increase of greenhouse gas emissions, the production PX by using abundant and renewable biomass instead of fossils has attracted widespread attention recently [3–5]. Substantial progress has been achieved in the PX production from biomass feedstocks over the past few years. In comparison with other methods (such as the catalytic pyrolysis or reforming of biomass [6], Gevo process from isobutanol [7] and selective conversion of bio-ethanol [8]), the reaction of DMF and ethylene ( Scheme 1) has been recognized as an effective route for producing renewable PX because of its high selectivity and technique feasibility [9–11]. As depicted in Scheme 1, the synthesis of PX from DMF and ethylene mainly includes two main reactions and several side reactions [12–14]. Among these processes, the DMF and ethylene first undergo Diels-Alder cycloaddition reaction, which can be efficiently catalyzed with Lewis acid sites. Then, PX is produced from dehydration of a cycloadduct intermediate (CH) catalyzed by both Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites [12,15,16]. Additionally, Brønsted acid sites also shows a high activity for the reaction of DMF and the produced water, especially for strong acid sites, which results in the formation of 2,5-hexanedione (HDO) byproduct. Subsequently, HDO further condenses intramolecularly to produce 3-methyl-2-cyclopentenone (CP). Moreover, some unknown byproducts (oligomers) and dimers (DM) can be formed in acid-catalyzed environment via the condensation reaction of HDO and the complex side reaction of CH, respectively [17,18]. Besides, the produced PX can react with the excessive ethylene to generate a byproduct 1-methyl-4-propylbenzene (AP) on the strong acid sites. Clearly, the type, quantity and strength of acid sites of the catalyst all play an important role in the selective production of PX from DMF and ethylene. To date, various heterogeneous catalysts with water resistance and tunable acidity have been evaluated in PX synthesis from DMF and ethylene, and great progresses have been obtained [5,19,20]. It was reported that phosphorous-containing Beta zeolite (P-Beta) showed excellent catalytic activity (99.0% DMF conversion and 97.0% PX yield) for the preparation of PX at 250 °C, 6.2 MPa for 24 h [21]. However, the zeolites are easily deactivated because of carbon deposition in its inherent microporous structure. Kim and co-works [22] reported that the PX yield was significantly increased from 8.4% to 75.8% by introducing mesopores into the pristine ZSM-5 zeolite at 250 °C for 24 h. The existence of appropriate mesopores in the solid acid catalyst is beneficial to enhance the mass transfer efficiency of the catalyst, which reduces the generation of coke and catalyst deactivation, thus improving the catalytic performance [17,18]. Metal phosphates also exhibited good catalytic activity for PX synthesis from DMF and ethylene because of their good mesoporous structure and abundant Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [23–25]. Yin et al. reported that 87.2% conversion of DMF and 76.5% yield of PX were obtained over NbOX-based catalyst (Nb2O5-NbPO4) at 250 °C for 6 h [23]. After that, Tan’ team found that SnPO also showed a better catalytic activity for the PX synthesis from DMF and ethylene with a DMF conversion of 99% and a PX yield of 93% at 250 °C for 18 h [24]. However, a large amount of NbOX-baesd catalyst or SnPO catalyst were required (≥ 12 wt%, based on the DMF mass) in the reaction due to the lower acid density (< 350 μmol NH3/g) and small specific surface area (< 100 m2/g), and the PX productivity of the NbOX-baesd catalyst and SnPO catalyst was 11.4 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1 and 14.5 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1, respectively. Furthermore, excessive surfactant was introduced in the preparation of these catalysts. On the other hand, the research on reaction mechanism is very scarce, and there are only a few reports based on DFT calculation and TPD-MS of DMF and ethylene adsorption [15,24,26]. While, an in-depth insight into the reaction mechanism is essential to the design of novel and highly efficient catalysts. Therefore, it is still urgent to develop a simple, efficient and stable solid acid catalyst with appropriate pore size, high specific surface area and reasonable acid sites for this reaction as well to further understand the reaction mechanism. Zirconium phosphate, an important kind of metal phosphates, is widely applied in many acid-catalyzed reactions, including dehydration [27–29], hydrolysis [30,31] and esterification [32,33], etc.. So far, various synthetic strategies have been reported for the preparation of zirconium phosphate such as refluxing, coprecipitation, hydrothermal, sol-gel and microemulsion [34–37]. However, the above-mentioned methods involved using phosphoric acid or a large amount of surfactant, and the resultant zirconium phosphate with a high specific surface area and large mesopores has been hardly reported. In this work, nanosheet-like zirconium phosphate catalysts with a high specific surface area, large mesopores and adjustable acidity were prepared via a facile surfactant-free hydrothermal method, in which NH4H2PO4 was used as a phosphorus source. All the synthesized catalysts showed outstanding catalytic performance for the PX synthesis. Moreover, the in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy was employed to investigate the adsorption of DMF and ethylene on the catalyst surface and the interaction between adsorbed species, in order to disclose the roles of catalytically active sites in the adsorption and reaction process and understand the reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials n-decane (99%), 3-methyl-2-cyclopentenone (99%), 2.5-Dimethylfuran (99%), 1,4-dioxane (99%), 2,5-hexanedione (97%) and p-xylene (99%) were provided by Aladdin (Shanghai, China). NH4H2PO4 (99%) and ZrOCl2·8 H2O (99%) were obtained from macklin (Shanghai, China). Ethylene (99.5%), nitrogen (99.99%) and 5% NH3 in He were obtained from Tenglong Chemical Co., Ltd (Xi'an, China). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterization Zirconium phosphates (ZrP-x, where x represents the value of P/Zr) were prepared in accordance with the following procedure. Typically, 5.75 g of NH4H2PO4 was first dissolved in 20 mL deionized water. Then, the solution of 6.45 g ZrOCl2 in 40 mL deionized water was slowly added into the above solution of NH4H2PO4 under vigorous stirring, and white precipitate appeared immediately. Subsequently, the formed mixture continued to be stirred for 6 h. After that, the above product was put into a 100 mL autoclave, and held at 100 °C for 1 day in an oven. The resultant samples was washed and dried. Finally, it was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h, and the obtained sample was denoted as ZrP-2.5. Other ZrP-x (x = 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalysts were prepared using a similar route with varying the addition amount of NH4H2PO4. Additionally, the as-prepared zirconium phosphates were characterized by various physico-chemical techniques, and the detailed methods were described in the Supplementary Materials. 2.3 Catalytic experiments The activity of the as-prepared zirconium phosphates for the PX synthesis was evaluated in a 50 mL batch reactor (Shanghai Rock Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd). Typically, a mixture of DMF (1.92 g), catalyst (2 wt%, base on DMF mass) and solvent (n-decane, 16.70 g) were put into the batch reactor. Then the reactor was purged with pure N2, and then was pressurized to 4.0 MPa with ethylene. The temperature of the reaction mixture was raised to 250 °C and kept for 6 h. After reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifuge, and the quantitative analysis of the resulting liquid mixture were determined by gas chromatography. The DMF conversion (XDMF), product selectivity (S i ) and PX yield (YPX) were calculated as follows: (1) X D M F = molesofconvertedDMF molesofinitialDMF × 100 % (2) S i = n × molesofproduct i molesofconvertedDMF × 100 % (3) Y PX = molesofproductPX molesofinitialDMF × 100 % Where i represent the product PX, cycloadduct intermediate CH, byproducts HDO, CP, DM and AP. When i represents the byproduct DM, the value of n is 2; otherwise, the value of n is 1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of zirconium phosphate The textural properties of the synthesized zirconium phosphates are presented in Fig. 1. Base on the IUPAC nomenclature, the synthesized zirconium phosphates possessed type IV isotherms. The ZrP-1, ZrP-1.5 and ZrP-2 catalysts had a H3 type hysteresis loop, whereas both ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 showed a H4 type hysteresis loop. The results suggest that the ZrP-x catalysts are typical mesoporous materials [28,30]. The pore size distribution curves in Fig. 1b confirmed that the ZrP-x catalysts contained abundant mesopores (2–50 nm) and macropores (50–100 nm). Besides, the detailed textural parameters of the synthesized zirconium phosphates are listed in Table 1. With improving the P/Zr mole ratio in the catalysts, the specific surface area of the zirconium phosphate catalysts increased firstly, and then reduced slightly. For the ZrP-3, the decrease in the specific surface area is likely caused by the formation of more crystalline ZrP2O7 phase in the ZrP-3 compared to ZrP-2.5. Among the synthesized catalysts, ZrP-2.5 exhibited the highest specific surface area (410.9 m2/g), a higher total pore volume (0.70 cm3/g) and abundant mesopores. The data is much higher than those of zirconium phosphates prepared by other synthetic methods [36,38]. The high specific surface area enables full exposure of catalytic active sites in the reaction, and the abundant mesopores promotes mass transfer of the catalyst. As a result, high catalytic activity would be expected. Table 1 also lists the P/Zr ratio determined by ICP-OES. It can be found that the measured P/Zr values were close to the set values for ZrP-1, ZrP-1.5 and ZrP-2. However, for ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 the measured P/Zr ratios were remarkably lower than those set values. The results suggest that the excessive P species was difficult to incorporate into the ZrP matrix during the preparation of ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3, which is in accordance with the previous studies reported by Weingarten et al. [27]. From XRD results of the synthesized zirconium phosphates (Fig. S1a), it is obvious that ZrP-1, ZrP-1.5 and ZrP-2 exhibited several of broad and weak peaks, indicating that these catalysts are amorphous. Both ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 showed two very weak diffraction peaks at 2θ of 33.9° and 21.6°, which can be assigned to ZrP2O7 (JCPDS, no. 36–0118). Nevertheless, the existence of two broad diffraction peaks and the missing of the characteristic peak of ZrP2O7 at 14.5° indicated that the crystallinity of ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 is very low. The functional groups of the as-prepared zirconium phosphates were determined by FT-IR (Fig. S1b). It is obvious that the similar adsorption peaks were observed in all the synthesized zirconium phosphates. The peaks at 3435 cm–1 and 1630 cm–1 were caused by the vibration of surface -OH and the adsorbed water molecule [39]. The broad and strong peak at 1087 cm–1 was caused by the stretching vibration of P-O-Zr bond [37,39], suggesting the existence of the phosphate skeleton. The peak at 752 cm–1 was caused by the deforming vibration of the P-O-P bond [37]. A low intensity vibrational peak at 518 cm–1 was corresponding to the Zr-O bond deforming vibration [40,41]. The microstructure and morphology of the synthesized zirconium phosphate catalysts were measured by TEM and SEM. As displayed in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2, it is obvious that the morphology of ZrP-x was remarkably influenced by the P/Zr mole ratio. ZrP-1 and ZrP-2 are loose blocks consisted of uniformly distributed nanoparticles, and the particle size of ZrP-2 is much smaller compared to ZrP-1, which led to a superior specific surface area of ZrP-2. When the P/Zr ratio was increased to above 2, both ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 exhibited lamella structure with a nanosheet thickness of ∼3 nm. The layer structure and the presence of abundant mesopores can effectively improve mass transfer, thus contributing to enhance catalytic activity [18,22,24]. The surface chemical compositions and valence states of different elements on the synthesized zirconium phosphates were determined by XPS. The survey scan spectra in Fig. S3a confirmed that the synthesized zirconium phosphates mainly include Zr, P and O elements. As depicted in Fig. S3b, the spectra of Zr 3d showed two characteristic peaks at binding energies of ∼185 eV and 183 eV, indicating the presence of Zr4+ in the as-prepared catalysts [37,42]. In addition, all the ZrP-x catalysts had a typical P 2p binding energy of ∼134 eV, attributed to P5+ (Fig. S3c) [39]. As the value of P/Zr was improved, a higher binding energy was observed for Zr 3d and P 2p, indicating the enhanced polarization of the Zr-O and P-O bonds, which could be caused by the increase of the -OH in the synthesized zirconium phosphates according to a previous study [41]. Additionally, the O1s spectra of the ZrP-x catalysts (Fig. S3d) were consisted of two peaks, which respectively appeared at ∼531.6 eV and ∼533.5 eV [37], while the binding energies of the deconvoluted O1s signal did not change regularly because of the diversity of oxygen-containing structure [41]. Furthermore, the surface P/Zr ratio determined by XPS in the Table S1 were all higher than those in the bulk of the catalysts (Table 1), indicating that surface enrichment of P species occurred during the preparation of the zirconium phosphates. NH3-TPD was employed to determined the acid properties of the synthesized zirconium phosphates and the corresponding curves are displayed in Fig. 3a-b. It can be clearly observed that all the synthesized zirconium phosphates exhibited a broad and strong NH3 desorption peak, suggesting the coexistence of weak (W, 100–200 °C), moderate (M, 200–350 °C) and strong acid sites (S, 350–550 °C) in the catalysts [43]. The total acid amount and the proportion of strong acid sites (S/(W+M)) according to peak deconvolution are summarized in Table 2. With increasing the P/Zr ratio from 1 to 2.5, the total acid amount of the ZrP-x catalysts improved greatly from 755 to 2057 μmol/g, which is likely due to the increase of phosphorous concentration. However, with further increasing the value of P/Zr to 3, the total acid amount of ZrP-3 decreased slightly. Although ZrP-3 has a similar P/Zr mole ratio to ZrP-2.5, the smaller specific surface area may reduce the exposure of acidic sites for the ZrP-2.5. As shown in Table 2, the proportion of strong acid sites (S/(W+M)) of the synthesized zirconium phosphates decreased slowly with increasing the values of P/Zr in the catalysts. The above data indicates that both the total acid amount and acid strength distribution of the synthesized zirconium phosphates can be easily regulated by tailoring the P/Zr ratio. The types of acid sites of the as-prepared zirconium phosphates was further investigated by pyridine FT-IR, and a detailed IR spectra are presented in Fig. 3c. The vibrational peaks at 1447 and 1610 cm−1 were caused by the pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites (PyL), and the vibrational peaks at 1541 and 1640 cm−1 were resulted from the pyridine adsorption on Brønsted acid sites (PyH+) [44]. Besides, the vibrational peak at 1491 cm−1 was caused by the pyridine adsorption on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [45]. According to the reported studies [27,28], Brønsted acid (B) and Lewis acid (L) in the zirconium phosphate catalyst were derived from P-OH groups and the coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV), respectively. The values of B/L were calculated according to the extinction coefficients, and the detailed results are listed in Table 2. When the values of P/Zr increased from 1 to 2, the B/L ratios improved greatly from 0.15 to 1.42. However, with further increasing the values of P/Zr from 2 to 3, the B/L ratios reduced gradually from 1.42 to 0.8. Similar results can be found in the previous literatures [27]. The above data suggest that the values of P/Zr have an important influence on the distribution of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the as-prepared catalysts. The chemical environment of phosphorus atom in the synthesized zirconium phosphates was detected by 31P MAS NMR, and the NMR spectra are presented in Fig. 4. It is clear that zirconium phosphates exhibited a very broad and strong resonance peaks, which could be ascribed to their amorphous nature [46,47]. In addition, it is obvious that both ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 exhibited four resonance peaks. More specifically, the peaks at − 10 and − 16 ppm in zirconium phosphates was respectively ascribed to (Zr-O)-PO(OH)2 and (Zr-O)2-PO(OH) [47,49], which primarily conduced to the formation of Brønsted acid sites because of the existence of abundant terminal PO-H. In addition, the peaks at − 20 ppm was assigned to (Zr-O)3-PO [47], which mainly contributed to Lewis acid sites. Besides, a broad and strong peaks at − 29 ppm were observed in the Fig. 4, indicating that there are many polyphosphate species (P-O-P species) in the synthesized zirconium phosphates, which could be caused by the condensation of phosphate species in the zirconium phosphates [48]. The previous studies also found that the P-O-P species can enhance Brønsted acidity of P-OH on the zirconium phosphate surface because of their strong electron-withdrawing effect [25,27,50]. The 31P MAS NMR spectra of the as-prepared catalysts were deconvoluted into four peaks corresponding to the above phosphate species of different coordination states by the PeakFit software, and their relative amounts in the synthesized zirconium phosphates are summarized in Table 3. When the values of P/Zr increased from 1 to 2, the amount of (Zr-O)-PO(OH)2 decreased slightly, but the amount of polyphosphates dramatically increased from 32.8% to 73.4%. Meanwhile, the amount of (Zr-O)3-PO remarkably decreased from 44.0% to 10.5%, resulting in a high B/L ratio for the ZrP-2 catalyst. The results are agree well with the Py-FTIR characterization data. With further increasing the values of P/Zr, the amount of polyphosphates reduced slightly, while the amount of (Zr-O)3-PO increased from 10.5% to 17.5%, resulting in a decrease of B/L ratio. The above results suggest that the chemical environment of the phosphorus atom can be adjusted via changing the values of P/Zr of the precursor solution, and then modulate their acidity. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the as-prepared zirconium phosphates for the synthesis of PX from DMF and ethylene were evaluated at 250 °C for 6 h. To enhance the hydrophobic environment of the catalysts and minimize the hydrolysis of DMF, the non-polar n-decane with a high boiling point was used as the solvent, and the detailed experiment results are presented in Table 4. As anticipated, no conversion of DMF was observed in the absence of catalyst. Compared with ZrO2, the ZrP-x catalysts exhibited a good catalytic performance for the synthesis of PX. Moreover, the values of P/Zr remarkably affected the catalytic performance of the zirconium phosphates, and a higher P/Zr ratio had a positive influence on the yield of PX, except for ZrP-3. Among these ZrP-x catalysts, ZrP-2.5 displayed the highest catalytic activity for the reaction, with a DMF conversion of 94.4% and a PX yield of 83.4% under the identical reaction conditions. When the reaction time further increased to 12 h, PX yield reached 89.2% with an almost complete conversion of DMF (> 99%). As shown in Scheme 1, the byproduct water is always produced along with the formation of PX at the second reaction step. Therefore, the effect of water content on the catalytic performance of the zirconium phosphates with different P/Zr ratio was investigated. As displayed in Fig. S4, with the addition of water (20 mol%, based on the mole number of DMF), the DMF conversion increased for all the zirconium phosphate catalysts, while the PX selectivity declined in different extent. It is worth noting that for ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3, the changes in DMF conversion and PX selectivity were less than 1.5%, indicating that the catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 with a lower proportion of strong acid sites was almost unaffected by the addition of water. The obvious increased DMF conversion and decreased PX selectivity for ZrP-1 should be caused by the presence of the higher proportion of strong acid sites in ZrP-1 that enhanced the hydrolysis of DMF and subsequent condensation [12]. Generally, the synthesis of PX from DMF and ethylene is a typical acid-catalyzed reaction [5,6,12]. Hence, the influence of acidity of the catalysts on the catalytic performance was explored, and the detailed results are presented in Fig. 5. With raising the P/Zr ratio, the DMF conversion increased from 78.8% for ZrP‐1 to 94.4% for ZrP-2.5 (Fig. 5a), which shows the similar change trend with the total acid amount of these catalysts. Further increasing the P/Zr value, resulted in a slight reduction for the DMF conversion, which could be caused by the reduction of total acid amount of ZrP-3. As presented in Fig. 5b, the ZrP-1 catalyst with the minimum B/L ratio of 0.15 revealed the lowest selectivity of PX and the highest selectivity of cycloadduct intermediate (CH), which is probably caused by the lack of enough Brønsted acid sites on ZrP-1 [18,23]. Moreover, the ZrP-1 catalyst exhibited the highest selectivity of AP and undetectable byproducts because of its high proportion of strong acid sites (S/(W+M)= 1.04), which can accelerate the alkylation reaction and the aldol condensation of HDO [17,18,51]. With increasing the P/Zr ratios of the catalysts from 1 to 2, the B/L ratios remarkably increased from 0.15 to 1.42, resulting in an increase of the PX selectivity from 74.6% (ZrP-1) to 83.1% (ZrP-2). This is due to that the increase of Brønsted acid sites efficiently facilitated the dehydration of the CH to generate PX. Although ZrP-2.5 had a smaller B/L value than ZrP-2, it revealed the higher PX selectivity and lower selectivity of CP and unknown byproducts. This is likely due to the fact that the ZrP-2.5 catalyst possesses the smaller proportion of strong acid sites (in particular strong Brønsted acid sites), which alleviated the hydrolysis of DMF to generate HDO, and then further conversion of HDO into CP, as well as the formation of some undetectable byproducts by the intramolecular condensation and aldol condensation [51,52]. With further increasing the values of P/Zr from 2.5 to 3, the B/L ratios slightly reduced from 0.96 to 0.8. The PX selectivity decreased from 88.3% for ZrP‐2.5 to 86.8% for ZrP-3. Table 2 shows that ZrP-2.5 and ZrP-3 have the similar proportion of strong acid sites (S/(W+M)). Thus, the results suggest that the B/L value of the catalyst plays an important role in the product distribution because an appropriate B/L value can simultaneously improve the Diels-Alder reaction and dehydration reaction, so as to enhance the PX selectivity. In comparison with the previously reported catalysts that have more strong Brønsted acid sites [5,12,14,19], the ZrP-2.5 showed a lower byproducts selectivity, which further confirms that a suitable acid strength distribution and B/L ratio are beneficial to suppressing the side reactions and decreasing the formation of carbon deposition. According to the above discussion, it can be deduced that the excellent catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5 can be ascribed to a combination of the existence of high acid density, appropriate acid strength distribution, and balanced amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the catalyst. To further understand the outstanding catalytic performance of the ZrP-x catalysts, the reaction kinetic experiments for the synthesis of PX were carried out on the four representative zirconium phosphate catalysts at different temperatures. The influence of stirring rate on the PX production rate was first investigated to eliminate mass transport limitation. As presented in the Fig. S5, the PX production rate almost did not change once the stirring rate was increased to 800–900 rpm, indicating that the mass transport limitation was eliminated. However, at the stirring rate of 1000 rpm, the PX production rate declined slightly because of the entrainment of partial catalyst particles on the reactor wall cause by the overhigh stirring rate. Hence, the kinetic experiments were performed in the batch reactor with a stirring rate of 800 rpm. The PX production over these selected catalysts at 220, 230, 240 and 250 °C are shown in Fig. S6. It can be seen that a clear linear relationship was observed between the production of PX and the reaction time. Based on these data in Fig. S6, the formation rate of PX (r PX) at various temperatures was obtained from the slope of the fitted straight lines. In accordance with the previous studies [13,23,24,53], for this reaction, since much excessive ethylene was added into the catalytic system and the catalyst dosage remained constant, the kinetic analysis for the synthesis of PX from DMF can be described using a zero-order kinetic model at lower acid site concentration, or a pseudo-first-order kinetics at higher acid site concentration, respectively. For the current catalytic system, Fig. S7 shows the effect of the acid site concentration on the formation rate of PX over ZrP-2.5. With raising the acid concentration, the initial formation rate of PX increased gradually and then maintained almost unchanged when the acid site concentration was ≥ 3.3 mM, in line with the previous reports [13,53]. According to the above discussion, it is obvious that the kinetic experiments in the present study were carried out at lower acid site concentration (≤1.6 mM). Hence, the kinetic analysis for the synthesis of PX can be described using a zero-order kinetic equation. Thus, Arrhenius plots was expressed as lnr PX plotted as a function of 1/T ( Fig. 6), and the values of apparent activation energy (Ea) for the synthesis of PX over the selected ZrP-x catalysts were obtained. Among the four ZrP-x catalysts, ZrP-2.5 has the minimum activation energy, followed by ZrP-3, ZrP-2 and ZrP-1. Thus, these results suggest that an abundance of active sites with lower reaction barrier were achieved on the surface of ZrP-2.5 through tuning the values of P/Zr. The Ea value of the ZrP-2.5 catalyst is 35.5 kJ·mol−1, which is lower than that of H-BEA catalyst (48.9 kJ·mol−1) [53], HY zeolite (41.8 kJ·mol−1) [13], SnPO catalyst (60.2 kJ·mol−1) [24] and NbOx-based catalyst (37.7 kJ·mol−1) [23]. As a result, a higher formation rate of PX was achieved on the ZrP-2.5 catalyst than other solid acid catalysts. 3.3 Effects of reaction conditions As displayed in Fig. 7a, with the elevation of temperature from 220 °C to 250 °C, the DMF conversion improved greatly from 69.2% to 94.4%. While the selectivity of PX reached the maximum value of 88.3% at 250 °C. With the further elevation of temperature to 260 °C, the selectivity of PX was reduced to 85.4% because of the increase of CP and undetectable byproducts derived from side reactions. It is worth noting that, even at 240 °C, the DMF conversion and PX selectivity could respectively reached 89.8% and 86.6%, indicating that the ZrP-2.5 catalyst also possesses an outstanding catalytic performance under the relatively lower reaction temperature. Fig. 7b shows the influence of initial ethylene pressure on the catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5. When the initial ethylene pressure increased from 2 to 4 MPa, the conversion of DMF improved from 75.5% to 94.2%, and the selectivity of PX also improved from 76.9% to 88.3%. The increased DMF conversion and PX selectivity could be caused by the fact that the solubility of ethylene in the reaction mixture increased greatly with the increase of ethylene pressure [12]. At the ethylene pressure of 2 MPa, the higher selectivity of HDO, CP and undetectable byproducts (Fig. S8b) indicated that the hydrolysis of DMF, subsequent dehydration and condensation were significantly enhanced because of the lack of enough ethylene during the reaction. As the initial ethylene pressure continued to increase, the DMF conversion and PX selectivity improved slightly. On the contrary, the selectivity of undetectable byproducts was drastically reduced from 16.0% to 5.8% with the increase of initial ethylene pressure from 2 MP to 5 MP. This could be ascribed to the fact that high ethylene pressure can improve the reaction rate of Diels-Alder reaction, and then promote the production of PX, thereby inhibiting the occurrence of side reactions, such as the hydrolysis of DMF and subsequent condensation [16,25]. Fig. 7c shows the influence of catalyst dosage on the catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5. As raising catalyst dosage from 1 wt% to 2 wt% of DMF, the conversion of DMF was improved from 86.5% to 94.4%, and the selectivity of PX was also improved from 85.4% to 88.3%. Upon continuous increase of the catalyst dosage, the conversion of DMF improved slightly, while the selectivity of PX was reduced to 86.0%. Meanwhile, the color of the reaction solution gradually darkened with the increase of the amount of catalyst, indicating the excessive amount of ZrP-2.5 facilitated the occurrence of side reactions, resulting in producing more oligomeric condensation products [18,54], which also can be confirmed by the quick increase of the selectivity of undetectable byproducts in the Fig. S8c. As displayed in Fig. 7d, the DMF conversion increased rapidly from 48.4% to 94.4% with extending reaction time from 1 to 6 h, and the selectivity of PX reached up to 88.3% at 6 h. When the reaction time was increased to 12 h, the DMF conversion and PX selectivity reached 99.1% and 90.0%, respectively. The corresponding PX productivity at 250 °C for 6 h was 72.3 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1, which is higher than those of the other solid acid catalysts, such as nanosized SnPO-1.75 (11.4 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1) [24], NbOX-baesd catalyst (14.5 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1) [23] and MFI zeolite (50.6 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1) [22]. Moreover, although the NSP-BEA zeolite also revealed a higher PX productivity at 250 °C for 6 h, it gave a lower PX yield of 60.9% [16]. More specifically, the comparison of catalytic performance between the ZrP-2.5 and the reported catalysts in the literature is shown in Table S2. It is obvious that the current catalyst presented herein is one of the most excellent catalysts for the synthesis of PX under relatively mild conditions with a lower catalyst dosage of 2 wt% DMF. The excellent catalytic activity of ZrP-2.5 for the PX production could be ascribed to a combination of the high acid density, appropriate acid strength distribution, balanced amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, and abundant mesopores. 3.4 Catalyst stability The leaching test of the ZrP-2.5 catalyst was conducted under 250 °C under 4 MP ethylene pressure. After reaction for 3 h, the catalyst was separated by filtration, and the resulting liquid mixture was re-added into the reactor and sealed. Subsequently, the ethylene with 4 MPa was filled into the reactor, and reheated to 250 °C for further reaction. As shown in Fig. 8a, no further reaction was observed after taking out the catalysts at 3 h, and the conversion of DMF always remained at ∼80%. Moreover, both Zr and P elements were not detected in the filtrate by ICP-OES, proving that the leaching of ZrP-2.5 did not occur, and the catalytic reaction is indeed heterogeneous. The reusability of the ZrP-2.5 was also investigated at 250 °C. After the first run, the used ZrP-2.5 was washed with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried at 100 °C overnight for the next run. As presented in Fig. 8b, both the DMF conversion and PX yield decreased greatly. As compared to the fresh ZrP-2.5, the TGA curves of the used ZrP-2.5 in Fig. S9a showed that an obvious weight loss was observed. In addition, the FT-IR spectra (Fig. S9b) further confirmed that small amounts of organic carbon species were adsorbed on the used ZrP-2.5 [24,55]. Therefore, in the subsequent runs, the used ZrP-2.5 was regenerated by calcination at 500 °C for 4 h in air for removing the adsorbed carbonaceous species. It is obvious that none of apparent activity loss was observed for the regenerated ZrP-2.5 catalyst after six cycles. And the regenerated catalyst exhibited comparable activity with the fresh one, confirming that the ZrP-2.5 catalyst had excellent reusability. The fresh and regenerated ZrP-2.5 catalyst (after the sixth cycles) were further characterized to examine the structural stability. As shown in Fig. S9b-c, both the fresh and regenerated ZrP-2.5 catalysts revealed quite similar XRD and FT-IR spectra. N2 physical adsorption (Fig. S9d) confirmed that the fresh catalyst had similar BET specific surface area with the regenerated one. NH3-TPD (Fig. S9e) showed that the fresh and regenerated catalysts had similar acidic density. Besides, SEM images (Fig. S9f) confirmed that both the fresh and regenerated catalysts exhibited similar morphology. To sum up, the ZrP-2.5 catalyst exhibited good stability in terms of structure and surface acidity. 3.5 Reaction mechanism of DMF with ethylene over ZrP-2.5 To in-depth gain the detailed information on the chemical interactions involved between the active sites of catalyst and feedstock, in-situ FTIR spectra of DMF and ethylene adsorbed on the ZrP-2.5 catalyst were performed. As shown in Fig. 9a, when DMF was adsorbed onto the surface of ZrP-2.5 at room temperature (30 °C), a numbers of IR bands were appeared. The bands at 2928, 2868 and 2962 cm−1 were ascribed to the C-H stretching vibrations of -CH3; the bands at 1450 and 1385 cm−1 were assigned to the C-H bending vibrations of -CH3 [56,57]. The bands at 1627 and 1583 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibrations and bending vibrations of CC bond (furan ring), and the band at 1553 cm−1 was associated with the C-C vibration between furan ring and -CH3 [58,59]. In addition, the bands appeared at 1232 and 1018 cm−1 were caused by the vibrations of C-O-C bond (furan ring) [58,59]. The negative peak at ca. 3670 cm−1 indicated that OH in P-OH groups (ZrP-2.5) were consumed by interaction with oxygen atoms of DMF [15,60]. The results suggest that DMF molecules were adsorbed on the surface of ZrP-2.5 via the interaction between P-OH in ZrP-2.5 and DMF. When desorption temperature improved from 30 °C to 300 °C, the band at 1232 cm−1 gradually moved to a lower wavenumber, indicating the presence of strong interaction between DMF and ZrP-2.5. From Fig. 9b, it can be seen that the introduction of ethylene onto the ZrP-2.5 catalyst resulted into the formation of a peak at ca. 1624 cm−1. The band at 1624 cm−1 was caused by the CC vibration of ethylene adsorbed on the catalyst surface via the interaction π-electrons with coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV) in ZrP-2.5 and CC band of ethylene [61,62]. When desorption temperature was improved to 250 °C, the characteristic peak at 1624 cm−1 completely disappeared. However, several characteristic IR peaks of DMF adsorption on ZrP-2.5 shown in Fig. 9a were still retained even at a higher temperature of 300 °C. The results imply that DMF molecules were more stably adsorbed on ZrP-2.5 than ethylene. The in-situ FTIR spectra of co-adsorption of DMF and ethylene were also performed to investigate the interaction between DMF and ethylene on the surface of ZrP-2.5. Fig. 9c shows the co-adsorption of DMF-ethylene in the range of 1000–2000 cm−1, in which DMF was introduced first, followed by ethylene. Fig. 9d presents the co-adsorption of ethylene-DMF in the range of 1000–2000 cm−1, in which ethylene was introduced first, followed by DMF. It is clear that both spectra reveal quite similar characteristic peaks whether DMF or ethylene was first introduced onto the catalyst surface. Moreover, the co-adsorption of DMF and ethylene in the range of 2000–4000 cm−1 were displayed in Fig. S10. It is clear that all the spectra show a negative peak at ca. 3670 cm−1, confirming that the existence of interaction between OH in P-OH groups (ZrP-2.5) and DMF whether DMF or ethylene was first introduced onto the catalyst surface. Thus, the results imply that there is no competitive adsorption between DMF and ethylene, further confirming that DMF and ethylene molecules were adsorbed on different active sites of ZrP-2.5. The adsorption of two types of active sites can effectively increase the concentration of DMF and ethylene on the ZrP-2.5 surface, which is helpful to enhance the reaction process. As shown in Fig. 9c, when DMF-ethylene molecules were co-adsorbed onto the surface of ZrP-2.5 at 30 °C, a number of IR bands were observed at 1681, 1627, 1597, 1450, and 1385 cm−1. In comparison with Fig. 9a, two new strong bands at 1681 and 1627 cm−1 appeared in Fig. 9c; whereas the C-O-C stretching vibrations at 1232 and 1018 cm−1 disappeared in the process. The band at 1681 cm−1 was caused by the CC stretching vibration of CH intermediate [63], and the band at 1627 cm−1 was caused by the CC stretching vibration of adsorbed ethylene [61,62]. These results suggest that new intermediate species (CH) were probably generated due to the interaction between DMF and ethylene co-adsorbed on the surface of ZrP-2.5. When the temperature was improved to 200 °C, the peak at 1681 cm−1 completely disappeared, the band at 1627 cm−1 decreased slightly in intensity, the bands at 1597, 1552 cm−1 intensified, and the band at 1450 cm−1 moved to 1460 cm−1. These four characteristic peaks at 1597, 1552, 1460 and 1385 cm−1 can be assigned to aromatic ring [64]. Thus, it can be inferred that PX was generated through transformation of the intermediate species. With the temperature was further improved from 200 °C to 250 °C, the characteristic peaks of PX further intensified, indicating an increased amount of PX on the ZrP-2.5 surface. Besides, a peak of CO bond at 1657 cm−1 was found with improving temperature, indicating the formation of HDO via the hydrolysis of DMF. In combination with the results of the experiment and characterization, as well as the previous literatures on the Diels-Alder and dehydration reaction [26,65–68], a reasonable reaction mechanism for the synthesis of PX catalyzed by ZrP-2.5 catalyst was proposed and shown in Scheme 2. The synthesis of PX from DMF and ethylene principally contains two steps, including Diels-Alder and dehydration reaction. During the reaction, DMF molecules are first adsorbed on the surface of ZrP-2.5 via the interaction between oxygen atoms of DMF and P-OH (Brønsted acid sites), and then the complex undergoes a Diels-Alder reaction with ethylene adsorbed on coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV) (Lewis acid sites) to form the cycloadduct intermediate (a1 and a1′). In the second step, PX is generated by dehydration of a1 and a1′ catalyzed by either Brønsted acid sites (P-OH) or Lewis acid sites (coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV)) as shown in Scheme 2. The dehydration process consists of three elementary steps, i.e., the C4-Of (furan oxygen) bond of the intermediate state a2 and a2′ is firstly broken, and then undergoes 1st proton transfer and 2nd proton transfer. Finally, PX together with equal molecular H2O is formed. In addition, based on the above discussion of adsorption properties, it can be inferred that P-OH in the ZrP-2.5 catalyst could have stronger interaction with the oxygen atoms from a2′ (or a2) ring than the coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV). Thus, the Brønsted acid sites from P-OH would be more active for the dehydration of cycloaddition intermediate (CH) than Lewis acid sites from the coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV), which is in accordance with the previous reports [16,26,68]. Therefore, it can be concluded that an efficient catalyst for this reaction should have a high acid density, balanced Brønsted and Lewis acid sites to enhance both Diels-Alder reaction and dehydration reaction. Furthermore, the catalyst also should have a suitable acid strength in order to minimize the side reactions, including the alkylation of PX, hydrolysis of 2,5-DMF and subsequent condensation. 4 Conclusion Amorphous zirconium phosphate catalysts with various P/Zr ratios were synthesized by hydrothermal method without adding surfactants. Among these catalysts, ZrP-2.5 revealed the most excellent catalytic performance for the synthesis of PX from DMF and ethylene, giving 99.1% DMF conversion with a PX yield of 89.2% under 250 °C for 12 h. The outstanding catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5 was attributed to a combination of high acidic density with appropriate acid strength distribution, balanced amounts of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, and abundant mesopores in the catalyst. The reaction kinetics analysis showed that ZrP-2.5 had a lower Ea (35.5 kJ·mol−1) in comparison with the previous reported zeolites and metal phosphates, indicating that more abundance active sites with lower reaction barrier were formed on the ZrP-2.5 catalyst. Consequently, a higher PX production rate was achieved. Moreover, the ZrP-2.5 catalyst showed excellent recyclability and structural stability. Hence, this work provides a simple strategy to design highly active ZrP-x for efficient production renewable PX from DMF and ethylene. We also believe the amorphous and mesoporous zirconium phosphate catalysts with tunable acidity can provide alternative approach for other acid-catalyzed reactions. coredata.dc:description: A series of zirconium phosphates (ZrP-x) with various P/Zr ratios were prepared. Among the catalysts, ZrP-2.5 with a high specific surface area of 410.9 m2·g−1 and abundant mesopores exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in the synthesis of p-xylene (PX) from 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and ethylene. A high PX yield of 89.2% and a productivity of 72.3 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1 were achieved at 250 °C using a small amount of catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance of ZrP-2.5 was attributed to the synergy between the large quantities of acidic sites with appropriate acid strength distribution, balanced Brønsted and Lewis acidity, and abundant mesopores. In addition, the catalyst had excellent recyclability and stability. In-situ FT-IR spectra of adsorbed DMF and ethylene revealed the crucial roles of P-OH and the coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV) in the adsorption and reaction process, which is beneficial to understanding the reaction mechanism and designing highly efficient catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient catalytic conversion of biomass-derived 2,5-dimethylfuran into renewable p-xylene over zirconium phosphate catalysts
